page.title: 01Sanquhar and its environs
page.content: Our reference area is based on the Royal Burgh of Sanquhar, which is in the Nithsdale District of Dumfries and Galloway Region in southwest Scotland. A small town with a population of 2200 Sanquhar stands on the main A76 trunk road and close to the River Nith. Once a mining area, Sanquhar has had to change its main industries since the closure of the two local mines in 1964. Our modern factories produce carpet yarns and tiles, school and office furniture, knitwear, plastic mouldings and fireworks. The town's chief employer is an aluminium processing factory. Originally called Saen Caer, meaning "Old Fort", Sanquhar and its environs are rich in history of both local and national importance-the "Sanquhar Declaration" and Britain's oldest post office being but two examples.
